CommentsContent: As a introvert, I have a hard time picking up on social queues and playing the social political game. I found this book to be very helpful in that regard. Would recommend.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 20, 2021
CommentsContent: This book was meant for people with good hearts who want to “boss up”. Unfortunately this book can be used for evil by evil people. I would say, be cautious when reading

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 30, 2020
CommentsContent: I am 15 years old, but I loved this book. It was full of intresting facts about history. It also gives a vary clear view of what power looks like, and how to twist it to your needs. It also paints a picture of how dangerous it is as well.

CommentsTitle: When trash and scumbags rule the world, only more trash and scumbags will be born
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 4, 2016
CommentsContent: This is a great book if you want to have the Armor of Knowledge equipped in your head. Certain laws contradict each other but the whole point is to use them when the need arises. There's 48 laws while during my lifetime, I will have countless encounters with people I prefer to avoid. Not just the workplace but school and real life I see not just stupid people but deceiving, narcissistic, and self-absorbed who want to shove your views down your throat. You can get respond back and crush their spirit (Law 15) or leave them alone for the insects that they are (Law 36). This book may be looked as manipulative but the people who have used these laws have their names carved onto History. And as a result, the Author has broken down their actions of the past and turned them into a guide on how to help and instruct the reader on how to master himself or herself and take on the world.  But then again this is how certain trash and scumbags are born. Genghis Khan, Count Victor Lustig, Yellow Kid Weil, King Henry (don't know which one), Mao Zedong (He lowkey uses this Man a lot). I'm giving this 4 stars outta 5 because there's some laws I wouldn't use. Maybe because I'm a nice guy but I prefer not to have ghosts from the past haunting my behind. The IRS can do that.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 11, 2017
CommentsContent: If you could mix The Art of War and The Prince, with some War and Peace mixed in, you'd end up with something like The 48 Laws of Power.I listened to this book on Audible originally but so enjoyed it that I bought a paperback copy as a gift for my cousin, then for my best friend, another Audible edition for another friend (who's listening to it for his second time now) then finally finding a hardcover for myself.The author names each law, gives an overview, and then gives examples throughout history of how these laws were applied correctly (and incorrectly). It's incredibly well-presented, and engaging all the way through. I thoroughly enjoyed it.If someone were to follow every one of these laws to a T, they'd probably be adopted by the Kims or something, but I don't think that is the intention here. Ultimately that comes down to you, the reader.With this book, you can see exactly they methods that others may use to keep you down, or hinder your opportunities while advancing their own interests. Many laws can safely be applied without putting others down to better yourself. Once again, that's up to you.Great book no matter how you cut it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 17, 2020
CommentsContent: The reviews on whether this book is moral or not aren't relevant: Greene makes excellent use of historical examples in proving each law, and history is based on facts rather than morals. Each law has been historically demonstrated, and a plethora of laws are plainly visible in the world today. A fantastic read on the different manifestations of power, how those have come to pass in history, and how you can usurp them (to a degree) for your own purposes. It spurred me to buy three other Greene books. Highly recommend, at the very least so you can become aware of how power manifests itself.

CommentsContent: This is a book about how to be a terrible person in order to get ahead in life. If thats the kind of person you want to be then read it. Basically lie cheat do whatever you have to do in order to get what you want no matter who you hurt.

CommentsTitle: Valuable life lessons for my teenage son

I liked it because it helped my son to understand many of the things I I have tried to teach him as he was growing up. In fact, he has has tells me he has been more successful using concepts when playing video games that involve complex social interactions. CommentsTitle: I could write A LOT of great things about this book

CommentsContent: I could write A LOT of great things about this book, but I'll just keep it simple:Wether you think you're interested in power or not, you have to read this book.Because from the moment you begin to read it, you'll (a) have your mind blow and (b) begin to truly understand what motivates people.Some of the rules will seem natural to you (i.e. Don't bite the hand that feeds), but others are far more eloquent.If you learn these lessons - truly learn them - you will avoid countless problems, and will come out the winner in a power struggle. CommentsTitle: Awesome. Painfully true and extremely enlightening

CommentsTitle: A Captivating, Eye-opening, and Unapologetic Foray Into The Realm of Power
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 15, 2017
CommentsContent: The 48 Laws of Power is a captivating, eye-opening, and unapologetic foray into the realm of power, and how to harness it for yourself. The chapters are beautifully structured with first the law of power in question, then a terse description of it, then in bulk you get an interpretation of the law that strings together many historical examples, and this is concluded by a reversal which goes over what situations the law may not be applicable in. This book is not an inquiry on the morality concerning the attainment of power. These laws were and will continue to be adhered by both the good and the bad. Law 26 is "Keep your hands clean"; this is how mafia bosses have often had the ability to orchestrate the most foul crimes with impunity. They are able to layer their command chain down so many levels that it makes it very difficult to trace the main perpetrator, the one commanding the crimes rather than those carrying it out. Law number 43 states that you should "work on the hearts and minds of others". Something like this was done by both Obama and Mao. Both for different purposes with different outcomes. The point is that by operating within the framework of the law helped both men achieve the higher level status that they obtained that enabled them to make a difference.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 13, 2014

It is an amoral NOT immoral look at Power Games throughout history and as Machiavelli's "Prince" a look into that world. It's action packed and hard to put down. It's practical and gut level. It's where reading that book that You look into Your own life and begin to compare and see Your own successes and failures comparing them to those principle that it hits hard. If nothing else it give a look into the shadowy world of the Global Elites and HOW they ALL operate in their own games in High Society and being aware gives You a safeguard in life to know the users and power game freaks out there. Another Must Read.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 25, 2014
CommentsContent: The best way to read this book is as a modern version of Machiavelli's The Prince.  Machiavelli was not advocating the ethos or ethics of what he was recommending; he was describing a brutally pragmatic and realistic approach to gaining and retaining political power.  Greene writes in much the sane way; this is not a book about ethics, it is a book about gaining and retaining power, regardless of position.  It also serves as a useful guide to things that people will do to you to gain power over you; it is important to understand these techniques to defend against them, even if you don't use them to gain power over others.

CommentsTitle: Understand the concepts dont try to implement you will destroy yourself

Now that is really destructive, like covey says "our perceptive governs the way we see, and how we see governs the way we behave", I read this book several years back and I can guarantee you, if you try to employ these means you wont be able to trust anybody and nobody will trust you either, if fact you'll become extremely suspicious of everyone's motives, things get complicated.How I would suggest you read this book is, read it for fun, these laws and their stories are very admirable but also understand them and ask a lot of questions as in "why does this work?", "could I have used this in the past", and once you're done with it, forget the law, just dont even think of it. Your mind is so beautiful, if you truly and deeply understand something, at the right time in your life, your mind will furnish you with it. So just understand it the content, enjoy his perspective and don't get sucked into it.And remember always in life, what you give is what you get.

CommentsTitle: A Good Man is Rarely Great and A Great Man Is Rarely Good
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 8, 2013
CommentsContent: I've read through the negative reviews for this book, men and women who hold high credentials, many liberals who compare these practices to the defunct companies and CEOs of the time.  They call it amoral, or outright manipulative.  News Flash for you, we are all manipulators, every decisions and choice we make in interpersonal relationships, is an act of manipulation.  The problem is that people rarely want to accept this dark truth and instead want to hold up the vale of selflessness believing that a life of sacrificing one's own happiness for the happiness of others is a true path to success in life.I am a liberal.  I voted Obama twice, I vote Democrat 90% of the time.  But, to say that politicians don't use these techniques to great effect to gain power would be ridiculous.  To say that Obama didn't use these effects... you must be kidding me.  His entire story in politics is one of Machiavellian rise.  Then, the negative reviewers mock politics, and say, "Well if you want to be a politician, than go for it."  This book doesn't promote stealing or defrauding people.  This book is about using and manipulating circumstances and events to have people elevate you to places of power by raising your status and importance.  This is not what Enron did that made it a bad company.  This is not what Dick Cheney did that made him a bad man.  This is not what Jack Abramaof did that got him put in jail.  It was the crimes, the theft, the defrauding, and the occasional murder. It is what got Dick Cheney put in power and what has happened to him.  Is he awaiting trial?  No he isn't.  Is he being put to death?  No, no... he's not.  Is he living high off of our money, able to travel the world with all the protection any man could ask for... yes, yes that does seem to be what he's doing.  Interesting... very interesting. Nowhere does this book recommend criminal behavior.  Nowhere does this book promote crime.  It promotes deception, it promotes using the true nature of human psychology that almost every leader has ever used.Whitewashed text books that talk about win-win scenarios are idealistic at best, plain wrong at most.  I'm someone who has read every one of them.  Social Psychology text books, Persuasion and Influence Textbooks, and have read the studies and methods.  Here's what we now know, an expensive piece of jewelry looked at from about a distance of ten or more feet away, while standing on a soft carpet is more desirable, than when standing three or five feet away on a soft carpet, however, even more desirable, when standing on a hard floor three to five feet away, but less desirable on a hard floor ten or more feet away.  This is why you'll see several stores using carpet in one area, and floor in the jewelry area.  It's not manipulation, it's using human psychology to your advantage.This is simply a book distilling what has worked throughout history.  Call me bitter.  I've had businesses undermined by people who have used these strategies, I've had girlfriends stolen by people who swept in with neurosis and need and creating false wants, it's only when I decided that everyone else is living a life the way they want it, and on their own terms, and I'm playing by mystical rules that few others are following that my life began to change.  When I threw away the morals and ethics and decided instead to embrace my life as my own and to live it with my full ability.Not only is this book a handy guide to getting and staying in power, it's a handy guide to watching people who are trying to take that power from you.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 2, 2011
CommentsContent: I bought this book because I am the only female working in an environment of men -- most commonly thirty-five to sixty men and most of them under the age of forty.  The environment can be empathic or hostile and can change its face at any given moment. Having deciphered those moments of change as moments of power grabs or diversions, I decided that I needed to understand how and why power is obtained.The 48 Laws of Power did help me understand how power can be obtained and did give me some defensive mechanisms to thwart unnecessary anxiety when struggles occur.  The divisive thought that arose for me while reading the book was the manipulative role of women in power. Can we really lose power by not showing enough love?  Can we be as aggressive as men in seeking power without making us more vulnerable?  Must we do without friends in such an environment?I agreed with the concepts of concealment, saying less than necessary, guarding reputations,not offending the wrong person, assuming formlessness, etc. However, in my work environment it is impossible to avoid the unlucky, use bait to get people to come to me, use generosity to disarm my victims, use absence to increase respect and honor,not build fortresses to protect myself, not offend the wrong person, play the perfect courtier,keep my hands clean, create a cultlike following, plan all the way to the end, or create compelling spectacles.I don't believe I could use many of the laws in daily practice, but the book did help me understand those who do and did increase my understanding of power brokers in a difficult environment.

Very highly recommended!

CommentsTitle: Power & Transformation, necessary and poorly understood by most.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 30, 2011
CommentsContent: You have lots of ideas about what POWER IS. Most of your ideas are probably wrong. It's not your fault. The news shows clearly 99% of people AREN'T powerful. Why? One big reason: a lack of readily available knowledge on the subject. Type POWER into Amazon search and you'll find a only handful of books on the subject, most of them mediocre. Same goes for the Internet. Don't you find that odd?People are only as good at something as they have learned and applied in their life. This holds true for everything, including power.The 48 Laws Of Power is one of the best books on the topic: Well thought out, well written, and well packaged. The formula is the same for Robert Greene's other books, as well.It's a big book with lots to digest and worth it. Best read one chapter per sitting. Then take some time away to reflect. That kind of a good book.I've read A LOT of books on the subject of Power. To save you time and money, here's a variety of other goods books on power: Power vs Force by David Hawkins, The Prince by Machiavelli, Art Of War by Sun Tze, On War by Carl von Clausewitz, Knowledge/Power by Foucault, Art Of Power by Thich Nhat Hanh, Anatomy Of Power by John Kenneth Galbraith, Secrets Of Power vol 1 & 2 by Ingo Swann, and Power by Jeffrey Pfeffer. These titles run the gamut from Spirituality to War to Government and Office Politics to Philosophy and more.What's missing from all these books? This: Power is different at every level of human development. What's needed is the additional  understanding that transformation plays in power. I coach clients daily in mastering their own power. When they learn about power they use what they have better and more wisely. They acquire more power while staying a "good guy". Most everyone both craves and fears power. As a result, they lack true power. They crave power because deep inside they feel powerless and a need to control others OR they fear power from a concern of abusing it. All this is learned in childhood and needs to be re-learned in an intelligent and healthy way in adulthood because power is at the core of everyone of us. It drives everything we do and we all need more of YOU.48 Laws Of Power is a solid read to help you understand both the strengths and possible consequences of many different kinds of power and power plays. Combine it with the previous titles and you'll possess a quality section in your library on Power. Hope this helps. Enjoy!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 17, 2009
CommentsContent:
Many of the reviews on here (okay, several, I only skimmed those on the front page) are critiquing the book solely as a self-help or business strategy book. That's fine; that's what the book is usually billed as.Yes, the laws provide important lessons on life. The reader may integrate them into their worldview as they and their moral sense sees fit.However, the laws themselves are just a small part of why I find this book so enjoyable, and why I feel compelled to take it off the bookshelf every so often. If you only want a run-down of Greene's laws, you don't have to look far for those (hint: if you don't mind squinting, it's called the "Look Inside" feature). But you'll be missing so much.Greene accompanies each of his laws with examples taken from history, myth and literature, demonstrating the advice followed as well as ignored, and the supposed ramifications of each path. Along the way, little anecdotes and excerpts along the same theme are included in the margins (this may be Joost Elffers' contribution).Whether or not you agree with Greene's conclusions (he is an English major and a writer, after all, not a world leader), reading how he interprets these stories and ties them to the main advice is highly enjoyable. You will be exposed to a lot of literary and historical references that you may not have been until now, and may pick up a number of ideas for further study.If you just want a list of platitudes and are not interested in the rest of the writing, then I would suggest you go right to the source with 

  
The Art of Worldly Wisdom









  
  
    
  . You will find that almost all of Greene's laws come from Gracian's 300 aphorisms in one way or another. Unlike Gracian's concise little manual, however, Greene offers a brief literary and historical study with each case that's certainly worth the price of admission. In fact, I recommend you buy both of the books.

I was against everyone else, and no one is to be trusted.Overall, it's a good experience to read this book. To have an glimpse into other people perspective in life. And in the end, it's all a matter of perspective

CommentsContent: I have just spent all summer reading and digesting this book and am  eagerly awaiting Greene's October release of "The Art of  Seduction."Nietzsche once wrote, "Anything truly productive  is offensive."  Offensive was my first reaction to "The 48 Laws  of Power."  But after careful reading I am convinced this is the best  book on practical psychology I have ever read.  Pay no attention to the  reviewers who say the laws contradict each other.  They don't.  They rather  compliment each other in the game of life.  Read in a spirit of adventure  (and with some humor as well) and you will find this book richly rewarding.  I wish I had had this guide years ago.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 20, 2014
CommentsContent: Robert Greene is well respected, and his books are all held in high regards- and rightly so. Instead of rehashing what everyone else has said, I'll briefly explain why this book should be a cornerstone on which to base your life.-This book will introduce you to the greatest Kings, Queens, Generals, Monks, Conmen, Magicians, Strategists, Seducers, scientists...the best the world has ever known. Should you find something to dig deeper into, you will already have a name to start your research with.- This book is not written as an academic exercise. There is nothing theoretical about this book. What you read can be directly applied in life.- These laws are timeless. Contrary to popular belief, the generations that come after us are no smarter than those who precede us.Technology, rules, governments, and societies as a whole may change, but people will remain inherently the same. To master this book is to be able to navigate through the masses and get to where you want to go in life.- You will learn to have direction. If you have dreams and goals, this book will help you figure out the basics of reaching out for help, for contacting others, knowing who to trust, etc.  Law 13 alone can change the course of a man's career- "When Asking for Help Appeal to People's Self-Interest, Never To Their Mercy or Gratitude."Study the book. Memorize the Laws. Highlight, take notes, and read seriously-You owe it to yourself. If you want to be the best, make it to the top of whatever field you're in- you will need this book.

CommentsContent: Although many other would see the contents of this books to be either cynical, deceptive, cowardly or even evil, I'd say it's a most valuable asset in our society to learn how to play the game of power.We all seek power in different ways: some seek it in love, others in money; others are simply intoxicated by the game, how it's played and how to bend the rules to their will. Those who have obtained true power didn't obtained it by mercy and compassion or empathy, but by trickery, deception, might and sheer willpower. Even the prophets like Moses, Muhammad and Jesus understood this well.Nevertheless I'd recommend this book to anyone interested in how the wolves of this world think and how to avoid such individuals, but in my case, the dark side of things all so sweeter...

CommentsTitle: Robert Greene's books are worth their weight in diamonds.
CommentsAuthor: Busy Reader: Get To The Point
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 17, 2008
CommentsContent: This book is a must-read for anyone who wants to live an independent life. You will encounter the challenges Greene writes about, and this book offers useful strategies for overcoming them.I know Greene's thinking is sound because I've tested it. With no business or technical education, I managed to increase my income 400% in just a few years. With my own money and leverage, I bought a house in the most expensive city [housing-wise] in America.Maybe your ambitions are different. Whatever you want, you won't get it without planning. All along the way, you must deal with people. You must get around or through them. This book is a great help. It is a masterpiece. I can't recommend it too strongly. I've read it through twice, listened to it on CDs and dipped deeply into Greene's bibliography. Read this book, you will never regret it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 26, 2013
CommentsContent: I refer to this book often when I have a work problem.  I have learned how to exercise restraint in what I say at work, how to delegate, and how to appear more powerful and confident than I really am.  Some of the advice you have to take with a grain of salt if you are not a "master manipulator"; however, it sheds some great light on the power struggles of history and how to apply them to modern day.  I don't share this book with many people, as I like to keep my strategies close to my chest, but it really helps to anticipate others' power plays and avoid pitfalls of being the "victim".

CommentsContent: I remember a friend at work recommended reading this book. He was going to let me borrow it(I bought the Art of Seduction and planned on reading it before reading this) and I would let him borrow the Art of Seduction; a book exchange. Unfortunately, my friend was fired so I didn't get the chance to borrow the 48 Laws.I had remembered  this, and went ahead and bought it. I thought it was better to read this first before the Art of Seduction. Before reading the 48 Laws, I began the Art of Seduction, but couldn't get into it.As soon as I began 48 Laws, I was intrigued. This was kind of book I was looking for. Because of my interest in the 48 Laws, I began the Art of Seduction again; reading these two books, side by side(not literally), I saw connections, and wanted to finish them; because of my curiosity, I wanted to see if these principles can be applied.I like the author's style of writing, explaining historical events, describing classical literary works; he would then explain observances and transgressions of these Laws, and how they can be interpreted.I really liked this book, and will come back to it again for another read.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 9, 2017
CommentsContent: From the second a friend of mine handed me his copy of this book, dog eared and highlighted throughout, I knew that I needed a copy. Since ordering it, I have done the exact same thing.Robert Greene outdoes himself in this work. His books are always pragmatic and geared towards realists. These laws that he describes are wonderful ways for dealing with even the smallest details of your life. Knowing when to speak up, knowing when to speak out, and knowing how to bring out the best qualities in yourself and others are integral parts of the business and social world today.Added to these tenets are stories of the laws in practice. What happens when you try to make your boss look bad? It happened to this person. Too shy to speak up - this is what happens. Need to re-invent yourself at work? Watch how this person did it.There is a situation for nearly every part of your life. And you will see in your own life places to apply these principles. And how to succeed with them.Disclaimer - if you’re a rosy optimist, this book is not for you. I handed to my wife, who amounted it to a book on manipulating people. It definitely isn’t, but it WILL show you how to maximize your potential.

CommentsTitle: Not relevant in today's world of abundance and choice
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 2, 2014
CommentsContent: It took away my confidence, making me suspicious and playing games with everyone, and made me lose some of my authenticity, which is actually my strength. It is aimed at a time in which you don't have much choice: Either you get to the top or you lose everything you have, so winning in the organization you are at is really a matter of life is or death. Today, on the other hand, we live in a world of free choice and abundance. What you get and don't get depends on your skills that are valuable to others. The more valuable and rare your skills are, the more freedom and power you will have. Freedom, because many will need you. Power, because you can demand more, the more valuable you skills.Today, you don't need power games. Instead, focus your time and energy on building your value for others rather than playing power games. The value you can offer to others will be a much more worthwhile investment, because with a high degree of value, you can exercise so much power and freedom that power games become irrelevant. If you don't like what your organization is offering you, but you have a lot of value, you can find someone else who is willing to offer you more, and simply state your terms. If they don't meet them, leave.This is the power of skill in today's world of abundance and choice.Focusing your energies on building your skill will make you more confident, make you feel better about yourself, and will bring you much more freedom and power than conspiring and playing power games will from the same effort.48 Laws Of Power might be valuable in a time of scarcity and lack of choice - When your life depended on being able to carve out as much as possible from the slight  slice of bread that was offered. In today's world, however, if you have something to offer, you can simply decide to leave the old slice for the vultures, and instead go and trade your skills for a much bigger and tastier piece which you can have all for yourself.For a book about how to achieve real power and freedom in today’s world of abundance, instead look at Cal Newport’s book “So Good They Can’t Ignore You”.

CommentsContent: Robert Greene interprets past events deciphering the rise and fall of some of histories most prominent figures. Greene emphasizes the point very well in each chapter, though no particular order puts one law over another.This makes a great prequel to The 33 Strategies of War

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 2, 2020
CommentsContent: This is a good read

CommentsTitle: Not laws, more like organized observations.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 1, 2013
CommentsContent:
I'm from science engineering background. A word like law, to me, applies to things like conservation of momentum, gravity, etc. Things which are simply put and true everywhere. With that title "48 Laws of Power" the author and publisher are setting our expectation for something like that. Unfortunately, the "laws" in the book are neither that simple, nor really set in stone.Every "law" is organized in a very systematic way. Starting with brief statement. Followed by a set of "transgressions" and "observations" of that law. Those are usually anecdotes/famous incidents from history, which illustrate someone breaking the law(transgression) or following the law to great effect(observation). These stories are followed by "Interpretation" which is essentially the author's analysis and opinion of situation, things like what were the intentions of the actors, what they did to achieve it, why they did it that way and why it worked. Each chapter ends with "reversal". Reversal is just an obscure way to say "Exceptions"As I'm reading these laws, (I'm already up to law 6) I am noticing that each law has exceptions, disguised as "reversals". This makes the title of this book very misleading. I wish there was a simple set of rules that we could follow to get power, unfortunately that's just not true.  It is very complex.I still like the writing of this book, it's interesting. I'd read it just for some food-for-thought, even though in the preface the author claims that reading this book for amusement would be irresponsible, which I don't understand at all.I have had this issue with many books, esp in the self-help category. A great example is 

  
Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus: The Classic Guide to Understanding the Opposite Sex









  
  
    
   where the author spends a lot of time in early chapters with fluff. One of the things he said was something to this effect "when I conduct seminars many couple approach me and say that we completely identify with your categorization but the husband feels like he's from venus and the wife from mars. That's completely normal, it's called role reversal". A glaring example of writing a whole book as if it's a law of nature and then sneaking in a "oh and by the way, it's perfectly normal to have an exception".Publishers need to advertise books like these as if they are laws of nature, to get a cult following. Unfortunately the truth is gray, complex. Complex material doesn't sell that well, so we are left with best sellers wh, skew our perspective and alter our reality to the point where we can no longer tackle the reality, the supposed purpose of the book.My advise is to read this very interesting book. But read it cynically. Evaluate it critically, don't submit your reality to it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 30, 2018
CommentsContent: So entertaining,, full of history and detailed accounts.Complaint: I  try to follow a story,  then the author cuts it off and interjects a completely different story before completing the original one. It's the most annoying thing about this book. If he's doing it to increase interest,  or power,  it didn't work on me. I already enjoy this book,  no need for that trick.Praise: in a world of humans full of ego,  the author gives valuable insight into human behavior. Some of it really doesn't apply nowadays like (crush your enemy completely), really,  does anyone kill their own children like that Chinese Empress that did anything to destroy her competition to the throne. Still I'm fascinated by human behavior so even these crazier stories were interesting to me.I consider myself very protective of innocents from deceptive individuals.  What better way to become a strong protector than by understanding the dark side of humanity.Ps. Not everything suggested will work. For example "If you want to seduce a woman,  court her sister first- Stehndal ". Someone i already liked tried this on me,  as soon as he mentioned my sister or any other women i banished him from my life. I know he's in pain rn and i love it.

CommentsTitle: Closer to The Form of Power
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 11, 2008
CommentsContent: Just what is power? I believe that through the amoral approach demonstrated in the 48 Laws of Power, Greene has gotten much closer to this answer and at the same time, gotten around many of the issues that plague discussions of power. This does not mean that ethics is not important when handling power, but rather, that power is morally neutral and is a tool that one can utilize within their own ethical systems. Everybody from the subjectivist to the altruistic individual can make use of power as it is defined in this text.While some may become disgusted at the ammorality and the examples that often show a "low brow" use of power, this does not take away from the value of this book, and in fact probably adds to it by showing how power can be used to harm others; someone could probably even apply Law 7 (which in part refers to using the wisdom of others) in order to create examples that show positive uses of power.Overall, I would recommend this book for anybody, but especially those studying Leadership and/or Politics.

CommentsTitle: Great Read, OVER-RATED as a life changing book.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 26, 2018
CommentsContent: 3.2 out of 5 ! Okay, let me be as real as I can.  The 48 laws of power is well researched, containing great applications of historical, poetic, & artisic examples.  The author seems to repeat & disect the same individuals to obtain "laws of power",  this comes off as a bit repetitive(for example, the sun king, napolean, the yellow kid, rothschild, etc).  The Laws are applicable to a degree.  The author potrays these laws as the reality of life, if you transgress the laws you will reap the consequences.  However, this is simply not the case.  A majority of these laws if applied will at the most give you a momentary gain, but in the long run will end up ruining your moral spine, and mold you into a lying con-man/actor, leading to your eventual loss not only of power, but even your social and physical life.(For example, Marco Bragadino is an example used as a observer of the Law of power, yet by applying the law in his life he gained an amount of power, only to be followed by losing his life, by swindling and conning, instead of just working for a living.)  Granted this book is an entertaining read, most certaintly a great collection of examples and sources to be meditated upon.  But, it should be noted this is not a view changing book as you see in most reviews.  This is more or less a great book to form you into a great-con man or fake individual(literally advising you to wear a mask around your personality, to avoid displaying your thoughts and intentions) not necessarily a powerful person.  It is a book I will keep in my library for the purpose as a conversation stater, or in obtaining sources.  Final thoughts.  This book is worth the read, but it is overrated in the reviews.  3.2 out of 5.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 22, 2010
CommentsContent: NOTE:  This is a review of the Kindle Edition of the book.  While it mentions the print edition, my rating is specific to the Kindle Edition.  If you are seeing this review listed in other editions of the book, please be aware that Amazon does this from time to time and unfortunately reviewers don't really have any control over it.The 48 Laws of Power is a fascinating journey through human history.  Its means of breaking up the lessons to be learned into "Laws" makes it both entertaining to read and a fascinating treatise on the nature of how people manipulate one another to achieve their goals.  I would hope anyone reading The 48 Laws of Power quickly figures out that this is not an instruction manual on "How to Conquer the World, All By Yourself"--it's entertaining, it's informative, but it's far from a get-rich-quick device.That said, one of the areas in which I am lacking in life has been the ability to truly understand and anticipate people's actions.  I can tell you that this book has greatly helped me to understand human nature a little better, and has even been useful helping me figure out when someone is trying to manipulate me.  I've been surprised at how much more I seem to be picking up on when it comes to others' personalities.  It also amazes me how across cultures and across the millenia, human nature stays very much the same.Unfortunately, the Kindle Edition of this book (which is where this review was written) is dreadful.  Typos are not a problem, but there are whole sections of this book that somehow got mangled in translation and it's clear no one took the time to proofread it.  The print edition of this book (which I also own) contains sidebars along the margins of many pages. For the Kindle edition, these side pieces are ungracefully dumped in the middle of a passage.  The mangled portions of this book are often unintelligible.I contacted Amazon about this and they responded that they unfortunately do not have any control over how well the publisher converts their products to the Kindle Edition.  It's cut back on my desire to purchase Kindle products unless and until the quality improves, and I do not recommend the Kindle edition of this book for this reason.  The print version, however, is certainly well worth the read.

CommentsTitle: Great book.........wonderful reading and learning experience
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 10, 1999
CommentsContent: After 44 years in the corp world of DuPont, General Electric, Black & Decker, Sunbeam, and Steelcase, I relate to all of the laws one way or another.Many of my mistakes in my career could have been avoided if I  had this book at my desk side.I was a naive, honest, ethical engineer,  manager, V.P., and President.......and was blind sided by my inability to  see the manipulations, dishonesty, political, manipulations of my trusted  leaders. My wisdom came too late.Business ethics be damned.........the  game is winning and gaining power forgetting the customer, company, the  employees and pleasing the shareholders and Wall Street above all to gain  personal reputation and be hailed by Fortune, Forbes, Business Week, etc.  feeding the ego trips of top management, taking credit for all that is good  and shedding the blame on others when things go bad.This should be  preferred reading in the Business Schools.A great job done by the  Authors.Al Lehnerd

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 25, 2013
CommentsContent: If I say this book saved my life it would seem like an exageration, but that's exactly how I feel about it.  Contrary to what some reviewers might write, in my opinion and experience this book doesn't turn you into a monster, but rather informs you well enough to see the monsters around you, how they operate in all manner of obvious or subtle ways to take advantage of you, and how you can avoid or deal with them.  Basically, it doesn't tell you to create pot-holes for others to stumble upon or fall into, but opens your eyes to see the pot-holes and how to navigate your affairs safely around them.  My business partner is a modern-day Shylock -- a manipulating, lying, greedy opportunist -- who doesn't hesitate to grab all she could under the disguise of a very sweet, caring friend who constantly says "oh, you're like family to me;" but underneath it all she's just hoping you'd make that one irretractable mistake of signing away your whole life to her.  If you're peace-loving and easy-going, a lot of people hardly ever fail to mistake your meekness for weakness, and even ride you like a donkey to their glory if they can.  I don't know about you, but it really hurts tearfully when you suddenly wake up to the realization that you've been taken for the fool of the century all along.  Thanks to this book for helping me see what's been going on.  And a very special thanks to my friend, Marie Guillaumes, the Editor of Illuminatista: Mind Alchemy by Juliette and Julie Williams, who listened patiently to my predicament and recommended this book to me.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 2, 2003
CommentsContent: The book deals with each of the 48 laws with a very wide selection of parables, myths, anecdotes and stories from all over the world and form all times, illustrating the unchanging dynamics of power over the centuries. It features Chinese warlords, Roman and renaissance-Italian power-mongers, American and European conmen, famous courtiers from the French courts before the Revolution, and even musings by Thomas Edison. And of course, the book pays tribute to the power-writer of all time, Niccolo Machiavelli.Learning the game of power requires a certain way of looking at situations and shift of perspective. To master the art takes effort, which requires certain basic skills, once mastered one is able to apply the laws of power.  The most fundamental of this skill is the ability to master your emotions.  An emotional response to a situation is the greatest barrier to power, a mistake that will cost you a lot more than any temporary satisfaction you may gain by expressing your feelings.  Emotions cloud reason, and if you cannot see the situation clearly, you cannot prepare for and respond to it with any degree of control.Anger is the most destructive of the emotional responses, for it clouds your vision the most.  It has a ripple effect that invariable makes situation less controllable and heightens your enemy's resolve.  Love and emotions are potentially destructive in that they blind you to the often self-serving interests of those whom you least suspect.The writings by Greene are an essential guide to power play.  They can help one be astute, alert, manipulative, cunning and provide an ability to strategize with the end goal in mind.  A clear grasp and understanding of the situation is a must.  The rhythm of power requires an alteration of force and cunning.  Too much force creates a counter-reaction; too much cunning no matter how well thought makes it predictable.The 48 Laws of Power is very cynical and depicts a world without mercy. The book is written in a manner so as to inspire the reader to achieve great power with an iron fist by talking directly to the reader, much like a self-help tape. Despite this belligerent and unabating tone, and the fact that it takes over 500 pages to get through all the laws, it is very readable, very clear in its message and the laws in it are not to be easily refuted.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 4, 2020
CommentsContent: Read this book awhile back purchased one for my sister!!

CommentsTitle: Buy it for the new college grad!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 20, 2013
CommentsContent: Love it.  This book is the PERFECT gift for the new college grad entering the work force.  I wish I read this 11 years ago when I graduated, it would have saved me a LOT of frustration.  I'm realizing all the mistakes I've made and surprisingly they would have been easy to avoid had I just had a little bit of knowledge before entering my career.I didn't feel that the laws were a serious threat to my morals.  Some of them, if taken to the extreme, certainly would be.  For the most part though, the majority of the laws can be used sparingly without feeling like you are selling your soul to the devil.I suggest taking personal notes after reading each law.  Reflect on the law and write down some ideas of how you can apply it to your life, decide if you are willing to use the law or if it violates your own personal morals, think of ways to defend against others who may use the law on you, think of ways that using the law might backfire on you, etc.  I did this and it was a huge help.  By the time I was done with the book I had a nice personal summary and "power plan" written out for myself.I noticed some reviewers who thought the laws sometimes contradicted themselves.  I agree to a point.  Sometimes they did.  I suppose the word "laws" makes it seem like they are set in stone and should always be true.  I tended to think of these laws more of tactics.  Some tactics work in certain situations and in other situations a contradicting tactic may be more suitable.I also found it extremely eye opening to the violence of life in the past.  If anything it made me more grateful for living in a modern and more civilized society.  Sure, the deception, back stabbing, and lies are still here today but at least you don't have to worry about getting your head chopped off.  At least when you get stabbed in the back today, it's metaphorically.  I mean, every story ended with at least one person getting their head chopped off or drowned or impaled with a spike.  Unbelievable.  I'm not just talking about lowly peasants either.  The kings / emperors / generals / courtiers / all seemed to be gambling with their life on a daily basis.  P*ss off the wrong person and your head went in a basket.

CommentsTitle: Survive and Thrive In a Competitve World
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 24, 2008
CommentsContent:
I picked this book up for $1, proof that there is no correlation between cost and value.

This would be the book that Machievelli would have written, had he courted the Aristocracy of his times, rather than attempting to ingratiate the Prince.

The author gives a hint to his motivations for this composition when he states in his acknowledgments:

"Finally, to those people in my life who have so skillfully used the game of power to manipulate, torture and cause me pain over the years, I bear you no grudges and I thank you for supplying me with the inspiration for the 48 Laws of Power."

This book is cathartic. But before diving deeper, a reader should be prepared to entertain the following ideas:

1. A Human being is no more than a sophisticated animal with self-interest as the primary motivator
2. Everyone wants more power, not less
3. Be true to yourself first and foremost, don't be a sucker
4. Power is a game and the better you play, the better your life will be
5. Power is essentially amoral and one of the most important skills to acquire is the ability to see circumstances rather than good or evil
6. To triumph, it is necessary alternate between being both cunning and formless
7. Beyond linear dualities of good and evil, there is a third dimension, the strategists' mind
8. The indirect path, that of influence is more effective and the use of it is an art

If you can live with the above, the 48 laws of power serves as a handbook on the arts of indirection.

This book argues that by mastering ones emotions, understanding the people involved and the fundamental dynamics of interrelationships within society determine the extent of ones accomplishments. Power is ultimately an artificial construct, given legitimacy by the people who participate in the game.

We need power to survive in a competitive world that is constantly seeking to recruit us into the ambitions of others. We can drain our lives in the fulfillment of others, or best use our given life, energy and talents at our own discretion. Implicit to this design is the belief that society defaults a role to you, whether or not that role reflects your beliefs and understanding about yourself. A choice then has to be made on your part to accept such a role or to resist whether in an active or passive way. In the latter sense, one will turn upon themselves. It is better then to assert some degree of control by exercising influence and demonstrating an identity that is consistent with the person whom we feel ourselves to be, in other words, to actualize ones' self. Although this end state transcends any particular identification, characterization or ego, the path to it requires a struggle and this book is about the methods and devices used by successful participants. The good news is, the struggle can be worthwhile, rewarding and the unexpected consequences enlightening.

The perfect archetypical master of the laws of power is the Courtier, who possesses more than anything, a talent to influence. Cognizant of how he is perceived at all times in a socially competitive world, the Courtier is ever vigilant to monitor his own effect, ever mindful of the elusiveness of power. I believe that this is what the author means by the Courtiers mirror.

The core realization is that more than anything, human beings are the most social of animals, so it goes without saying that the most socially adapted animal attains the best that life has to offer. Human beings also possess Consciousness to such a heightened degree, that they can deliberately break and follow a path in defiance to their instincts and conditioned or learned behaviors, unlike animals.

In a paradoxical way, learning to play the game of power teaches virtues of mindfulness, patience and mastering ones ego. In this sense, the book permits another legitimate path to the completion of ones life without blindly accepting a given religion.

Well written, argued and referenced, it is abundantly clear how the author reaches his conclusions. It is highly accessible and well digested for the reader. There is a great deal of truth to the idea that a book serves as a mirror for the reader and I am hard pressed to argue against the wisdom contained in this manual. There is great peace of mind to be had from accepting fundamental truths.

Some would read this book and walk away with the impression that this is a "how to" on manipulation. Beware of such people, as their delusions make them a danger to themselves and anyone who places trust in them. You need not become a con artist to derive benefit from what is contained here. The laws of cause and effect and the aphorism of "Know thyself" are embedded as living proof, ignore them to your peril.

CommentsTitle: Great book, but I won't "behead" my workers.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 11, 2018
CommentsContent: Robert Greene spends the entire book reminiscing on powerful people throughout the ages so one can learn from history instead of being doomed to repeat it.While I must say that this is one of the most useful and fun books I've read in a long time, the fact that he teaches powers compliment, subserviency, leads me to believe that Robert himself is pompous. As a "master" myself, as Robert would say, I have no intention of "beheading" my workers for going above and beyond the call of duty. Quite the opposite - I reward those generously who work to grow within the company. If one of them kissed my feet, I'd send them away as I'll not have people worshiping me.You know what "masters" want from their employs? Work. The single greatest thing you can do to make your boss smile is to simply work. So many people take on a job only to sit there watching TV and not working on what they're supposed to do, and as any steward of a company, I have one of my managers send them away.As for the rest of the book, if you can get through the overzealous nature, and even downright evil nature of some things, you can learn some very interesting information.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 25, 2014
CommentsContent: 48 laws of powerI will not begin this review with a list of the 48 laws but I will tell you that this is one effective book. True we are past the age of kings and queens and royal courts are no longer dens of aristocracy striving for power . None the less there are small fiefdoms , work places and parties where people jockey for position and power. The quest for power has to be in a civilized fashion. Outburst and violence will not be tolerated.The book starts off each chapter with the given law of power then goes into application. The first application is transgression, what happens when you fail to follow the law. After that the author goes into how to properly observe the law and apply it. In some chapters it does talk about reversing the law.Every chapter is filled with incidents pulled from history. On the side lines are fables and stories that help illustrate the point. The history alone makes this book top notch. Macciavelli, Baltasar Gracian, aesops fables are richly quoted here. mr. Greene is a student of the history of power.I cannot enthusiastically reccomend this book enough.  Mr. Greene has several other books out and I plan to read them . No matter your walk of life or aspiration you will get something out of this.

Now I'm reading the ones I glossed over.If you're ambitious and / or looking to understand how power is used by others against you, this book will open your eyes to the why and how behind it and who it benefits.  Would Recommend.

CommentsTitle: A "Bible" or a "Warning", depending on who you are...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 26, 2014
CommentsContent: There are a lot of other great reviews on here, including the 1 star reviews (which is unusual...) so I'll let people be a lot more vocal than me in describing the pros and cons of this book.I think there is a difference between liking the material in this book, and having respect for it's contents and construction.  The book is very well written, but it's contents may be offensive to certain people and a gold mine to others.There is no doubt that anyone putting these tactics and principles to work in their everyday life will result in them being something of a sociopath and a megalomanic.  If you are an incredibly ambitious person who seeks power and domination at all costs, then this book will be your bread and butter!  (I am NOT one of those people.)However, even if you find the inner workings of this book offensive and anti-social, the books is STILL valuable as a resource that you can use to find out what games other people are playing against YOU.  In that respect, I would still put this book high on a list of books you should read.  If you want to swim with the sharks and not get eaten, this book will illuminate what you need to look for to protect yourself from ambitious power mongers.If you really want to have personal power without resorting to Machiavellian tactics, I would recommend "Aikido In Everyday Life" by Terry Dobson and Victor Miller.  That book shows how to use the principles of the martial art Aikido to be strong and in harmony with others (and to totally kick ass in almost any situation!) without having to be an upward mobility seeker or sociopathic power monger.If you want to be a U.S. Senator, then THIS book is for you!  (Yes, I am disgusted with our government.)Peace!

CommentsTitle: Wow, I wish I'd read this years ago
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 20, 2013
CommentsContent: Wow is all I can say about this book. I wish I had read this years ago. This is like my secret weapon that I almost don't want to tell anyone else about. I've already used some of the laws to my success. This book is simply amazing. I won't go too deep into the actual 48 laws of power. That you can discover for yourself. I'll talk about some of the other great features of the book.1) It outlines 48 rules that will help you create and maintain power over yourself, over others, and your environment2) The author supports these rules with interesting historical anecdotes3) The book is outlined in such a way that you can easily skip around to the rules most relevant to you. However it's recommended to read the book in it's entirety4) The overall layout of the book is captivating, with the main laws of power, their anecdotes, and then fables, poems and smaller examples in the margins, with each chapter closing with a unique twist.After getting half way through The 48 Laws of Power, I came back to Amazon and purchased Robert Greene's "The Art of Seduction" and preordered Greene's "Mastery".

CommentsTitle: A Must Read for People With a Purpose
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 29, 2014
CommentsContent: Downloaded this book at the suggestion of one of my students last night.  Really like it.  Caught me off guard as it is written in a similar style(in my opinion) as the  "Art of War" (one of my favorites) is written in.  Based on the author's bio was expecting something more trendy, but once I went back and read the preface the style made sense in that he is cherry picking some of the best ideas about power over the last 3000 years - not just pop-culture stuff.What I really liked about it is a reader can just pick off one of the laws per day, and dive as deep into each as one wants. Any one of the 48 can increase someone's awareness, an help them better achieve their purpose.  Nice to have a book that has more than just one main idea and 155 pages of dribble surrounding it (like most bestselling business books).In summary, this is going on my informal book recommendation list.  I think it is one of those few books that I have seen that is interesting enough to actually make time to read in a few days, but will take a life to master.  Wish I had this book when I was in my 20's.Best,Brian Vanderjack, PMP, MBA  Recent HBR Linkedin "Top Contributor" (out of 500,000 member community)  Email: BVanderjac@Gmail.com (put "48" in the subject and will read your replies)  Linkedin: [...]Ps.  FYI  - There are about 1000 versions of the "Art of War," and their approaches to the material vary widely.  If you are interested in checking it out, definitely skim a few of them at the library to find one that works for you before you invest in one.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 19, 2014
CommentsContent: The 48 laws of power may not be nice, they may not be what you aspire to, and they may not be the world in which you wish to live.  Unfortunately, Robert Greene has nailed down 48 truisms that need to be understood by anyone responsible for managing, leading, selling, cajoling or subjected to any of those things.Greene takes the best and worst of human psychology and masterfully integrates lessons from history, quotations from classical literature and an entertaining if somewhat pedantic writing style to make the reader alert to the approach.  Reminding this reviewer of the tone taken by Machiavelli in "The Prince", Greene aims to both instruct and entertain while not passing moral judgement on the contents.Learn the 48 laws.  Understand that they are derivative of our nature, sociology and psychology, and accept that the information in the book is useful - if at times unpleasant to comprehend.

CommentsTitle: These are simply options, not requirements
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 2, 2014
CommentsContent: The way to read this book is to look at the 'Laws' as options presented by the author.The book is divided into chapters that discuss each 'law.' While the word 'law' really makes the idea seem universal and absolute, these are really options and tactics. Following the description of the tactic is a set of historic parables and fables that demonstrate the application of it.The exercise for the reader is to figure out the best situations to apply each tactic. The purpose of this book is to really expand your thinking and make you aware that certain options exist. Many of us immediately dismiss certain actions as unconscionable or unethical, but this author challenges that dismissal. He wants us to think about all of our options objectively in the context of our overarching goals, and not be too quick to dismiss ideas out-of-hand.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 16, 2014
CommentsContent: one of the best book about these matters. Only the 36 chinese stratagems can be defined as more intuitive (even if more difficult to understand in everyday life). This book will unveil a bitter truth about human beings: all human beings, included your family, your friends, colleagues...all of us search for personal satisfaction, which could be money, sex, political power. Based on this assumption, a lot of behaviours could be observed. Most of them have common roots. This book not only list them but give you clear and (interesting) examples, through human history. Which is to say: hey guys, we all know that this sucks, but we are not the only ones to behave in this way...look at Napoleon, Talleyrand, Sun Tzu, look at Michelangelo, etc, etc. As Baldasar Gracian said (also reported into this book)...most of our power in society is not based on what we DO, but on what we avoid to DO. I suggest this work without any basic arguments.

CommentsTitle: Read 48 Laws for yourself and make an informed decision
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 29, 2010
CommentsContent: Many of this book's negative reviews seem to focus on its supposed immorality.  Reading these reviews can be a bit misleading because they make it seem as if the only types of people who can use these laws are those wishing to deceive and manipulate others.  Admittedly, this is somewhat true (you most likely aren't reading a book like this if you aren't looking for a way to influence other people more effectively) however the way a person chooses to apply these laws is really what determines their morality.  Even some of the seemingly duplicitous laws are in fact fairly innocuous.  Take for instance, taking the credit for other people's work.  On the surface, this appears to be rather despicable.  But if you've ever read a self-help book or attended a motivational seminar, and then applied the principles you learned, then you have used this law.  This in fact, is one of the best aspects of The 48 Laws of Power; at no point does Greene try to tell the reader what's right and wrong...only what works.Content aside, the book is laid out and reads well.  As you would expect each law gets its own chapter.  Chapters are broken down into a brief description of each law backed up by historical examples of transgressions and observances concluding with Green's personal thoughts.  There are also anecdotal stories and poems in the margins.  While the examples of transgressions and observances do a good job of illustrating the point, I found Greene's commentary to be extremely insightful as well.  Most chapters can be read in thirty minutes or less which leads me to another positive aspect of this book; you can read a chapter right before you go to bed and literally begin applying it the very next day.  Even if you don't apply them you will most certainly notice people following or (more often) breaking them.As far as the laws' effectiveness I don't have personal experience with them all, though the ones I have applied work great.  Many of them are situational.  Others aren't always necessary (that is to say, following them will certainly help your cause but ignoring them won't necessarily be detrimental).  Still others are indispensable and not following them will at a minimum limit your potential (particularly in the work place).  48 Laws is basically a human psychology book and how you use it is really up to you.  In my opinion, if you change even one pattern of behavior as a result of reading it then it was worth the money.  And even if you don't, it will at least give you new insight on human interaction.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 2, 2013
CommentsContent: Wow, I can't believe I finished! I've been chipping away at this book for probably six years now. It is amazingly researched and organized, a great compilation for either offensive or defensive maneuvers in life. The only reason it took me so long to read is because it is DARK. When I got to the example of a concubine in ancient China poisoning a baby because it was an heir to the throne, I had to take a break. There is no way I am willing to go that far to gain power, and doing battle against someone who would is an unsettling concept.Greene specifically states that his books are amoral, not immoral, and that may technically be true. Still, whenever I felt my soul shriveling into a crumpled, blackened speck, I knew it was time to read something more positive for a while. Therefore, I had a very on-again off-again relationship with this work. But these are the rules of life they didn't teach us in school, and I can't wait to start "The 33 Strategies of War."

CommentsTitle: Packed full of wisdom throughout the ages. Both unabridged and abridged editions are excellent
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 16, 2015
CommentsContent: "The 48 Laws of Power" was a wake-up call for me. It reminded me of Machiavell's "The Prince" which I read in high school. However, I thought "The Prince" had no relevance to my life since I did not need to decide whether or not to chop the head off a defeated king.Robert Greene's book helped to make the connection between Machiavelli's principles and methods and what I have experienced in my professional career. While nearly everyone claims to be straightforward and honest, some are adept at maneuvering themselves into advantageous positions. "The 48 Laws" explains the many tools these individuals use to increase their power, usually at the expense of yours. I have found the most valuable books to help me learn about life through the experiences of others and this book is packed full of wisdom throughout the ages.Several of the 48 laws that were insightful to me were:Law 1 - Never outshine the masterLaw 4 - Always say less than necessaryLaw 9 -  Win through your actions, never through argumentLaw 16 - Use absence to increase respect and honorLaw 20 - Do not commit to anyoneLaw 29 - Plan all the way to the endLaw 38 - Think as you like but behave like othersLaw 46 - Never appear too perfectLaw 48 - Assume formlesslessA few of these may sound obivious, silly, puzzling. However, there are plenty of historical examples to explain each law (in the form of "observance of the law", "violation of the law", and "reversals"). I may use a few of the laws in the future but mostly, I will be aware of the laws to watch my back.Both the unabridged and abridged versions are excellent - 'Machiavelli's ¨'The Prince¨ on steroids. If you have the time, go with the unabridged edition because it has many more historical examples. However, if you are time constrained, the abridged version is terrific as well.I first listened to the abridged version and found it to have many pearls of wisdom. As the author suggests, I identified many examples of the laws in my professional and academic career. I wished I had read (or listened) to this book earlier in my youth.I then listened to the unabridged version because I was interested in the full text and it did not disappoint with many more historical examples - ¨the wise learn from the mistakes of others.¨

CommentsTitle: Great ideas, but could have been conveyed better
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 7, 2017
CommentsContent: I give this four stars mainly because I was bothered by formatting and the examples given in the book.  The laws themselves are well thought out and backed up with examples, but nearly every anecdote in the book brings the reader back 500 years into a time that wasn't necessarily relatable.  I give the author credit in the sense that history repeats itself and the examples are still valid, but it would have been nice to read a mix of contemporary and a mix of historical anecdotes.  I just found the book a little bit slow given I was reading about kings and queens and wars the entire time.  Power is a subject applicable to ALL domains, and I felt this book was a bit narrow.Also, I found it very distracting how the author includes one-off snippets between stories that are totally unrelated.  It disrupts the flow of the book.All that said, this book is well worth the read.  I just wouldn't suggest reading it like a normal book.  This is one of those books you just have to pick up over and over again and read little snippets of.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 21, 2016
CommentsContent: Reading this book was fun, although sometimes it made me feel like a bad person. Some sentences are written like "and then your unsuspecting sheeplike victim will never see it coming"...and for me that sort of language is a bit extreme. Why must power be equated with evil? Anyhow, I especially enjoyed the historical examples Greene uses to support his ideas. In terms of content, I cannot at the moment name more than two or three laws of power and their application. Now, I read this a few months ago, and few of the lessons seemed to stick with me. Maybe that's because there are 48 laws to memorize, or perhaps only a few jumped out at me. All in all, I liked the book, and internalized several of these laws of power.

CommentsTitle: It gets boring reading speculative theories about power which are either entirely ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 23, 2015
CommentsContent: The content could have been more condensed. It gets boring reading speculative theories about power which are either entirely intuitive to begin with or impractical. The author spreads a depressing worldview where the goal of life is to deceive and manipulate everyone around you, while ignoring the forms of power which are available in life through more virtuous paths. What I like about the book is that it offers a very diverse selection of fables and historical stories from across many times and societies which clearly illustrate power.

CommentsTitle: Like the bible for jerks, but sadly true.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 24, 2013
CommentsContent: This book is like the bible for jerks. Basically everything that Jesus was and taught this book is the exact opposite of. If you want to learn how to be a completely amoral person who seeks their own self-interest and only that, wherein others are mere pawns in the game of success that have no value whatsoever, this is the book for you. I think almost everything it teaches is morally wrong, but I gave it four stars anyway. The reason why is because almost everything in this book is true. I think there is a difference between truth and correctness. I believe if you follow the laws written in this book there is a very good possibility you will be successful. You might end up with no friends and a completely superficial identity, but it is the path to material success. In that sense it is true. I think it is not correct in that the morals of it are wrong. Essentially the problem with the ideas taught in this book is that it requires there to be dupes who do not follow these rules, because if everybody followed them society would collapse. What I would say is that if you don't want to be what is described in this book, you can use it to identify other people who are and steer clear of them or anticipate their moves before they make them. In that sense it is a good book even for the morally decent among us.

CommentsTitle: Power corrupts. And absolute power ... well, you know.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 28, 2017
CommentsContent: This book is a well written analysis of how power might be obtained and maintained. The negative reviews seem to believe that Greene is encouraging everyone to act immorally. I can see where certain people would believe this. What I took away from this book is that many people act in ways that may be harmful to us and if you better understand what they are doing, you stand a much better chance of removing yourself from danger.Of course, some people with delusions of grandeur will imagine that they can follow the "rules" of this book and go on to conquer the boardroom, the media or even the world. Good luck with that.The fact is that most people who operate in these theaters already know and practice all or many of the "rules." There is nothing new here for anyone who has been educated well since they will have already been exposed to Machiavelli and the many lessons of history. Still, this book is very entertaining and instructive.

I placed them at their seats prior to class and allowed them to enter the room w/o me being present for the first five minutes. CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 30, 2013
CommentsContent: I have recommended and bought multiple copies of this book for many friends. Once you read it, it's like someone removed dark glasses from in front of your eyes. Suddenly history makes sense to me and politics even more. This book is not a novel and actually reads like a text book. It is amoral meaning that the information in it can be used either way. Not IMMORAL where the information can only be used for evil. The example I give is like this: This book is like money. One can used it to help others or use it to buy weapons to kill. Morality comes from your application of the knowledge. Gandhi was a master of the information in here, so was Napoleon and even Hitler. Don't read it fast. Take your time. It will change you too (for the better).

CommentsTitle: What you actually want to know before buying the Kindle edition.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 17, 2010
CommentsContent: My review is based solely on the quality of the Kindle edition.  For the most part it is great.  There are a few little errors in spacing, spelling, and general format issues.  I'd say you get 2 or 3 for each "law".  The bigger problem is that there are a few spelling errors so egregious that you have no idea what the word is supposed to be.  That happens every 3 "laws" or so.  I gave it 3 stars because these mistakes are annoying enough that they should create a new Kindle edition, but not so bad you'd demand your money back.  If you are reading this, these are the types of reviews you should be writing for Kindle books.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 22, 2011
CommentsContent: If you're an historical aficionado, you will love this book, although it's more of a hindsight chronicle of how certain powerful individuals manifested their epic legacies, rather than a guidebook.  Agonizingly detailed, voraciously researched, the lessons will be a bore to slow readers, replete with dense references and margin-notes (candy for dweebs!), but succeeds as a multifarious playbook on how to map your trajectory to world domination.  Many lessons/rules contradict one another and The 48 Laws of Power is above all a notebook of previously tried and true applications, many of which will not work in all situations and which require a discerning eye for proper application.  Nevertheless, for those refined individuals patient to read about the successes and failures of predecessors across the globe and throughout the annals of history, it is an undeniable gem of psycho-historical analysis. I recommend this book to anyone who must deal with people of power/money/status, and adults who've never mastered playing with children in the sandbox.

CommentsTitle: The 3 Laws of Reviewing Robert Greene
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 19, 2007
CommentsContent: 1The law: Read Robert Greene's books lightly, dipping into them from time to time. Perhaps when you wake up in the morning, or before stepping out to go to work, or before going to bed. Don't read the books cover to cover in a few sittings. Let yourself absorb their lessons.Reversal: Read lightly but pay attention. Don't think yourself above these laws. Greene presents to a modern audience lessons from the classics of human literature. Do not dismiss the wisdom of ages lightly.2The law: Let the laws and strategies that Greene has sifted from the classics guide you in your everyday life. The lessons of the past have already been paid for. Do not reinvent the wheel.Reversal: Do not insist on applying a specific law to a specific problem. Let a situation choose its own solution. Do not force a square peg in a round hole.3The law: Empathize. When asking someone for something, for instance when emailing Greene hoping for a reply, offer them something of value to them.Reversal: Accept that anyone can refuse when asked for something. Robert Greene receives too much email to reply to all messages. Move on to another author.Image: A library full of other books.Vincent Poirier, DublinYes, yes. I used the same basic review for all three of Robert Greene's books. That's OK. Robert Greene wrote the same basic book three times. But at least it's three times the same good book.

CommentsContent: i recommend this book to anyone who is tired of being controlled or being betrayed. this book teaches you how people control each other and how to play the game of life. there is a chapter in the book" never trust friends too much- learn how to use enemies. this chapter will show you how to never confide in any friend totally and it will tell you why. nothing is wrong with a little manipulation,life is about moderation and life is a game. sometimes it's either play or be played. the book also shows why yellow kid weil was able to con people out of millions of dollars. the book has a historic context which shows you how men like otto von Bismarck applied the laws of power. there are 48 of them choose the ones you like and apply them. this book is not for the weak but its for the people who want to play the game of life and never lose.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 16, 2014
CommentsContent: It does not matter if you want to play the game or not, you are in it. You don't have to take a sword with you but for heavens sake at lest wear some armor. This book is that armor, to understand the 48 laws allows you to see the oppertunity/danger before it is to late. NO, I WILL NOT HURT PEOPLE FOR GAIN but I will no longer be used if I can help it.I came in early and stayed late to get the job done. I have recieved great reviews and many promises of money and promotion. All for little. I noticed my peers, who were not as dedicated as I by their own admission, careers were moving along at the same pace as mine or faster. When I had enough, I began to talk to managers that I trusted and employees who have had success in career advancement. Guess what, their comments and advice were very similiar to many of the laws in this book.This book is very "Practical" and, while I admit, practicing many of these laws would be "Dangerous" and "Shameless" to ignore that they are present in our every day lives is delusional.
