CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 10, 2010
CommentsContent: I love this book and own it in paperback.  But I bought the Kindle edition and am quite disappointed to find out how sloppily it is put together.  Many words that are intended to be italicized are not.  Extra lines are are put where they're not needed and are not put where they are needed.  Some words are misspelled, e.g., "TOLSIOY" for "TOLSTOY" (OCR error?).  The margin notes are interspersed at arbitrary places in the text, interrupting the flow, instead of doing something more reasonable like putting them all at the end of the chapter.  There is an index that is completely pointless since there are no references to where the words are used (it would have been better just to leave it out entirely).If I were the publisher, I would be embarrassed to have my name on this Kindle edition, regardless of price.  And how on earth can they charge $16.99 when they are not even doing basic proofreading?!? ...let alone actually putting some thought into adapting it to the Kindle?  Is this a joke? CommentsTitle: Outstanding text. Must read for cooperate people, big or small!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 1, 2013
CommentsContent: I have listened to the audiobook version of this great text when I was at university, though I didn't have the physical book, I found the 'laws' were naturally introduced to me via lots of short but interesting stories, despite it is hard to go back and forward and cross reference things without the book.I bought the paperback and now I also own the kindle version of the book. And I have read it twice. (I kept the paperback book as a useful reference in my small bookshelf which has not been increasing in quantity since I became an ebook reader.As I read the text, I can understand though the theories have been termed as 'laws', nothing is certain, the author has used lots of examples to illustrate examples which seems contradictory but it is really a true facet of working in any company/corporation: you need to see through the reality and make the right decision based on the conditions you are in.The only thing I am not satisfied about this book is the examples which are sometimes too far away from our times, if he could even make up examples, say, as a consultant in Goldman Sachs dealing with certain issues, that will make the book even more useful.I have to say, as a young graduate working for a big American firm and have seen the harshness of life in it along with my idealism forced to wither till its eventual vanquish in such a short span of 2 months, I recommend this as one of the principal texts in dealing with people. But don't be stubborn, no situation is exactly the same, you have to use the way of thinking illustrated in this book rather than following the 'laws' stubbornly and literally.

Putting it all together over the course of 24 hours was too much for me. Those are 24 hours that I could have been learning spanish or talking to my grandma. I understand why this book exists and why some people would want this sitting on their shelves, but it goes way overboard on normal social situations. I work in a government, military branch, so bits and pieces were relevant to previous careers or social situations, but not many. I guess if you're a NY banker trying to make partner you might want to look through a paper version of this book. Interpretation: Read something else.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 13, 2012
CommentsContent: I'm the type who, "buys me now, reads me later..." type of book buyer.  I first tried to read Robert Greene's book some time back, I couldn't get into it. So I put it to the side for the time being....A)  In 2012 I began reading "Sun Tzu For Success" by Gerald Michaelson and Steven Michaelson. As a result my eyes were opened to the possibilities in how to see the big picture in the success planning. As well as how thinking in proactive mode can produce stronger results than  reaction thinking like most of us would do.B)  So when I finally read "48 Laws", it was like life-lessons reading in how to get along with people. Or how immature people will behave toward you. Which I never understood since most of us know about morals, ethics and family-values in our civilized society of the 21st century.C)  The biggest chapter for me was Law#24; "Play the Perfect Courtier". It's how to play internal politics either at work or in social groups. Wow!, what an eye opener.D)  Or how about Law#46: "Never Appear Too Perfect". Your efforts to be ambitious, successful or even just plain charming can create envy and people hating you for no reason but for you being at your best.E)  Another is Law#18:"Do Not Build Fortresses to Protect Yourself-Isolation is Dangerous" It's what happens when you are work alone and cut yourself off. You lose "being out of the loop" from very important information to dominate from.F)  Even if you are a person of high character and a good person. Your friends and working peers won't always see the world the way you do. So protect yourself from these bad people.F)  SO YOU MUST BUY THIS BOOK!... IT'S TODAY'S BIBLE!So now I'm reading "The New Boss" by Peter Fischer. "How To Survive the First 100 Days" whether starting a new job or new to a group. I'm using "48 Laws" like a reference book for when I observe a behavior and ask why are they?... Combined I stand a better chance to not just survive but thrive in my ever changing environments!Enjoy!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 6, 2014
CommentsContent: The title of this book could have been "48 Methods Other People Use To Try To Have Power Over You" because that's what it's really about. It's 48 things that people do to try to influence, control, or manipulate others. You can read an overview of the 48 laws in the "Look Inside" link on the book cover at the top of the page.I wish people didn't do these things. I wish people didn't act this way, but I've found out the hard way that people do. As one reviewer said, other people don't live by the same rules that I do. This has caused me problems in the past. Now I understand what I am sometimes up against, not always, not with everyone, but sometimes with some people.Reading this book caused me to think a lot. I remembered times I've seen other people do these things to others. I remembered times other people had power over me because of them. I thought about times I may have used these methods on others. Not all of them are bad. Some are smart and helpful like making your boss look good, or not outshining your boss (causing him or her to feel insecure and not like you and cause you trouble).Each law has a story or two describing what it's about and how it works. The examples are from a time in history when these power games were the social norm. We're talking from the 1600's and 1700's with Kings and Emperors and the common people. There must have been different social dynamics at play back then because some of the rules are totally whacked out. For example, they treated their friends as pawns in a game to use for their own advantage, and they recommended hiring your enemies because they would be more loyal than friends. Say what? They also said to guard your reputation, but hey, if you trash your friends to get ahead, you have no reputation, especially with FB and Twitter and blogs. So not everything can be applied in today's world, but there is enough value here to give it 5 stars.It certainly gave me a different viewpoint in life so I can be ready to work with different kinds of people. Different companies have more or less of these at play, depending on who the managers are. I think a bad environment can draw out the worst in people, and a wonderful company culture with a supportive environment can draw out the best in people. I don't believe a person posing as a friend, working as a spy, scheming to get ahead on the job would last very long in a company with a wonderful upbeat company culture. I also don't think a nice person (oblivious of these laws) would last very long in a company who thrives on competition between employees. What you don't know could hurt you.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 18, 2014
CommentsContent: This is a 14 year-old book that I, then my wife read. After 1330 reviews, what else might possibly be said?We'll ... maybe a lot. Notice that the reviews have trended up toward 5 stars after a sketchy 3-5 star beginning 13 years ago. Are the 48 Laws of Power more relevant now than 13 years ago?Reviewer's terms have morphed from using words like `evil' in some form to `practical' and `useful' today.  Are readers more aligned to the 48 Laws then they were in 2000?My wife and I have our own book club thing going so we've spent some time chatting about Greene's 48 Law's. We agree first, that Lucifer and the demons of Hell should have gotten some of the credits in the intro. However, Greene elucidates the Hellion's strategies so well that they are likely enthralled by the result since the low key, take no credit for injecting is one of the laws. That's not to say that we mere humans don't execute the possibilities of this list of management style temptations ... at least 2 or 3 a day ... maybe more.We agree second that the 48 Laws of Power is a masterpiece. It describes the ways and means to reap what you sow. it is so exceedingly rare that an author sticks to such ancient tried and true methods that really work without messing them up with "New" or "Improved" notions. This is hard core wisdom for the power seekers and office warriors.  You can love it or hate it simultaneously. Nonetheless,  it is worthy simply because it is so spot on for offence or defense in a wholly secular world.Great value for money ... a long read.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 1, 2014
CommentsContent: My local public library used to have 5 copies. They have all been stolen. I work as a correctional officer in a county jail. This book is very popular among the inmates. It's mostly for that reason I considered it a must read. If you're a kleptomaniac, you can steal it. If you're a pyromaniac, you can burn it. If you're a masochist, you can have someone read it to you, If you're a sadist, you can read it to someone. If you have a Pollyanna view of human nature, you'll most likely not like this book. It will make you think. It's worth many of the history lessons alone.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 19, 2013
CommentsContent: Robert Greene does it again. This book is filled with true "laws" that you can observe in everyday society. Regardless if you agree if the laws are "right or wrong" morally is beside the point. These laws are a bit dark and somewhat Machiavellian but they are very applicable to modern day society. Knowing the laws from this book will help you understand the dynamics of power, how to use it, or how to defend yourself from those that try to use it against you. Even if you aren't looking to gain power, this book is still eye opening. I highly recommend this book to anyone.
